column1: Taguig (pronounced [taˈɡiɡ]) is the seventh most populous city in the Philippines
column2: and the fourth most populous city in Luzon with a population of 804
column3: 915 people. Located in the western shores of Laguna de Bay
column4: the city is known for the Bonifacio Global City
column5: one of the leading financial centers of the Philippines. Originally a thriving fishing village during the Spanish and American colonial periods
column6: the municipality experienced rapid growth when former military reservations were converted by the Bases Conversion and Development Authority (BCDA) into mixed-use planned communities and financial centers. Taguig was converted from a municipality into a highly urbanized city with the passage of Republic Act No. 8487 in 2004.

column1: The original farmer-fishermen of the area
column2: about 800 in number
column3: were good at threshing rice after harvest. Hence they were referred to as "mga taga-giik
column4: (Tagalog for rice thresher") and the settlement as "pook ng mga taga-giik." Spanish friar Fray Alonso de Alvarado
column5: together with conquistador Ruy López de Villalobos who crossed Pasig River to reach the city's present site in 1571
column6: found "taga-giik" difficult to pronounce. "Tagui-ig" was later shortened to its current form "Taguig".

column2: Taguig was a part of Namayan and Tondo ruled by Lakandula. There were also accounts that Chinese settlements were once present in the area as revealed by the recent archaeological diggings of various artifacts like cups
column3: plates and other utensils
column4: which bear Chinese characters. This was believed to have originated from China's Ming dynasty.

column1: Taguig was one of the earliest known territories to have been Christianized when the Spaniards succeeded in subjugating mainland Luzon through the Legazpi expedition in 1571. Between the years 1582 and 1583
column2: Taguig was part of the encomienda of Tondo headed by an alcalde mayor
column3: Captain Vergara. It was in 1587 when Taguig was established as a separate "pueblo" (town) of the then province of Manila. Captain Juan Basi was its Kapitan from 1587 to 1588. According to records
column4: Taguig had nine (9) barrios then namely
column13: and Wawa. Records show that Tipas had once petitioned to become an independent town but was denied by the Spanish government.

column2: Taguig was accessible via the Pasig River
column3: which was connected to two large bodies of water
column4: the Manila Bay and Laguna de Bay. The population then was estimated to be 800 tributes. The town produced more than enough rice for consumption but had less sugar cane to mill. The men lived through fishing while women wove cotton cloth and "sawali" from bamboo strips. The people of Taguig were known to have resisted both Spanish and American colonial rule. During that early period of Spanish colonization. Don Juan Basi
column6: took part in the Tondo Conspiracy
column7: an attempt to overthrow the Spanish government which failed. Basi was exiled for two years as punishment. When the Katipunan was on its early years
column8: many from Taguig became followers and later joined the uprising. The people of Taguig also joined the revolutionary government of General Emilio Aguinaldo on August 6

column2: they struggled against the forces of General Wheaton under the command of General Pio del Pilar. It was recorded that on February 6
column4: Filipino forces including Taguig "revolutionarios" dislodged an American position in the hills of Taguig
column5: now a portion of Pateros and Fort Bonifacio. They were defeated eventually by the Americans with superiority in the armaments and training. Taguig finally fell to the contingent of the First Washington Volunteer Infantry led by Col. Wholly.

column1: The defeat of the Filipinos after two years of struggle against the American forces subsequently subjected the Philippines to another system of governance. On August 14
column3: United States occupied the islands and established a military government with General Wesley Meritt as the First Military Governor. He exercised legislative powers until September 1
column4: 1900. At the start of American occupation
column5: Taguig was proclaimed as an independent municipality with the promulgation of General Order No. 4 on March 29
column6: 1900. The town was subsequently incorporated to the newly created province of Rizal when the Philippine Commission promulgated Act. No. 137 on June 11
column10: Muntinlupa and Pateros were merged by the virtue of Act. No. 942 with Pateros hosting the seat of the municipal government. The merger did not last long as a month later Muntinlupa was segregated from it and made part of Biñan when Act. No. 1008 was enacted on November 25
column11: 1903. However it was returned to Taguig on March 22
column13: with the promulgation Act. No. 1308. On February 29
column15: Taguig was again declared an independent municipality through Executive Order No. 20. Eventually
column16: Pateros separated from Taguig and both became independent municipalities of Rizal province on January 1

column1: It was also during the American Colonial Period that the US government acquired a 25.78 km2 (9.95 sq mi) property of Taguig for military purposes. This large piece of land
column2: which had a TCT dated 1902
column3: was turned into a camp that became known as Fort McKinley (named after William McKinley
column4: 25th president of the U.S.). When the Japanese occupied the Philippines in 1942
column5: Fort McKinley was taken over by the Japanese Imperial Army. They occupied the military camp until the end of the war in 1945. After the Philippines gained its political independence from the United States on July 4
column7: the US surrendered the Republic of the Philippines all right of possession
column9: supervision and control over the Philippine territory except the use of the military bases. On May 14
column11: Fort William McKinley was turned over to the Philippine government by virtue of the US Embassy Note No. 0570. Fort McKinley was made the permanent headquarters of the Philippine Army in 1957 and was subsequently renamed Fort Bonifacio after the Father of the Philippine Revolution against Spain

"state-of-the-art" 17-storey Taguig City Hall is currently being built in Barangay Ususan along Cayetano Boulevard and is expected to be completed in 2021. This will replace the current city hall in Barangay Tuktukan that was built in 1959 and was renovated thrice.

column1: The climate of Taguig is characterized by two types of season: dry season from November to April
column2: and wet season from May to October. Rainfall is less evenly distributed.

column1: Like other cities in the Philippines
column2: Taguig is governed by a mayor and vice mayor who are elected to three-year terms. The mayor is the executive head and leads the city's departments in executing the city ordinances and improving public services. The city mayor is restricted to three consecutive terms
column3: totaling nine years
column4: although a mayor can be elected again after an interruption of one term. The vice mayor heads a legislative council consisting of 18 members: 8 councilors from the First District
column6: the president of the Sangguniang Kabataan (Youth Council) Federation
column8: and the president of the Association of Barangay Chairmen (ABC) as barangay sectoral representative. The council is in charge of creating the city's policies in the form of Ordinances and Resolutions.
